Organs/Tissues: Any single organ or tissue type: e.g. liver, heart, lung, kidney, tumor, etc. ALine designs device per user’s specification.
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Normal physiological flows, mechanical cues, or disease conditions (infection, hypoxia, drug toxicity).
Cell Source: Any: cell lines, primary cells, iPSC-derived organoids, tissue slices, ex vivo samples. ALine customizes materials/coatings accordingly.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, can incorporate co-culture or multi-cell layering in a single organ environment. Valves & compartments for complex interplay.
Stromal Cells: Yes, if user needs fibroblasts, mesenchymal cells, or ECM-embedded stroma. ALine can design 3D scaffolds or matrix inserts.
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, can embed immune cells in the tissue compartment or design a reservoir for them. Depends on project specs.
Circulating Immune: Yes, if requested. Fluidic channels can be used to flow immune cells over an endothelium or tissue slice.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): For single-organ chips, not typically. But they can still have dual compartments. Multi-organ is a separate offering. They can do partial crosstalk within one device if user requests.
Air-Liquid Interface: Possible if user needs alveolar/skin model. ALine can integrate a porous membrane with an air compartment, or an open well design.
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, solutions for 3D hydrogels or scaffold integration. ALine chooses/laminates appropriate materials for user’s ECM approach.
3D Scaffold: Yes, can embed or clamp a scaffold in the chip. Possibly place organoids or tissue slices in a perfused chamber.
Notable Features: ALine fully custom builds. Integrates microvalves, on-chip pumps, or sensor layers. Laser-cut laminate or CNC plastic. Solutions are robust, user-specific.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Custom. Usually single device for detailed study. Low throughput by default but can replicate multiple units if needed. Possibly adapted to well-plate footprint if requested.
Max Culture Duration: Days–weeks. By design, can incorporate recirculation, bubble traps, stable environment for long-term viability.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, typically uses transparent layers or glass windows. ALine ensures microscope compatibility if needed.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, fluidic ports can be added for effluent collection or sampling loops. Possibly on-chip sample storage if user wants.
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Can design openable or flushable compartments. Typically includes protocols for retrieving cells or lysis in situ.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: If requested, chip can be made openable or use removable inserts. Alternatively, in situ imaging or post-fixation cut-out.
Readouts - TEER: Yes, if integrated at design stage. ALine can embed electrodes for measuring barrier function or supply ports for external TEER probes.
Readouts - MEA: Yes, if user needs neuronal/cardiac electrophysiology. ALine can incorporate embedded electrode arrays or align chip with external MEA.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Core strength. They can add on-chip O2, pH, glucose sensors, optical detection paths, or electrochemical sensors as required.
Dead Volume: Minimized by careful design. ALine uses short fluidic paths, microvalves to reduce waste and ensure fast response.
Perfused: Yes, fundamental. Solutions can have on-chip pumps/valves or external connections. Flow profiles are user-defined.
Gas Mix Controlled: Customizable. Typically rely on sealed environment or media-based oxygenation. ALine can incorporate gas-permeable or impermeable layers as needed.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, advanced. On-chip valves/pumps can deliver dynamic stimuli, cyclical flows, automated protocols, feedback loops with sensors.
model_availability: Service-based. ALine custom designs & fabricates devices for each project. Not a catalog item – user provides design goals.

Model: Custom Multi-Organ or Advanced Integration Solutions
Organs/Tissues: Multi-organ-on-chip or multi-chamber systems connecting multiple tissues (liver-kidney, gut-liver-brain, etc.).
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Complex crosstalk modeling – e.g. healthy synergy or pathologies like metastasis or systemic inflammation.
Cell Source: Any required by user: iPSC-derived organoids for each organ, primary cells for multi-organ synergy, etc. ALine ensures each organ’s compartment is suitably designed.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, each organ chamber can host distinct cell populations (hepatocytes, cardiomyocytes, endothelium, immune cells).
Stromal Cells: Yes, each organ module can embed fibroblasts or stroma relevant to that tissue (e.g. hepatic stellate cells, cardiac fibroblasts).
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, e.g. microglia in a brain chamber, Kupffer cells in liver chamber. Chambers can be connected by fluidic channels for cross talk.
Circulating Immune: Yes, the fluidic network can route immune cells from a blood-mimic reservoir through multiple organ compartments sequentially or in parallel.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Key feature. Perfusion loops connect multiple organ compartments, simulating body-level interactions. Valve systems can isolate or link tissues at chosen times.
Air-Liquid Interface: Possible in one or more compartments if needed (e.g. lung alveolus). ALine can incorporate membranes or open wells.
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, each organ compartment can have 3D scaffolds or matrix tailored to that organ. Complexity as required by user.
3D Scaffold: Yes, can incorporate multiple 3D tissues or organoids. E.g. liver spheroids in one chamber, kidney tubules in another.
Notable Features: Highly complex fluidic networks with on-board valves for routing media among organs. Potential for integrated sensors or custom mechanical cues.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Custom. Usually 1 multi-organ chip is one experiment. Possibly replicate for moderate throughput. Not a standard multi-well plate. They can build parallel arrays if the project demands.
Max Culture Duration: Days–weeks. ALine can design large or recirculating volumes, embedded sensors to maintain stable multi-organ viability long-term.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, each organ chamber can have optical windows. They might place them in an array for parallel imaging or a single chip with multiple viewports.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, from any chamber outlet or integrated sample ports. Possibly automated fraction collection if on-board valves are used.
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Chambers can be made accessible or openable. End-user can retrieve cells from each organ separately if designed so. Or do in situ lysis.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: If user requests removable organ inserts or scaffolds, they can. Or do on-chip histology/immunostaining. They can design the device for straightforward organ chamber extraction.
Readouts - TEER: Yes, if barrier compartments exist. ALine can integrate electrodes for each organ barrier. Or rely on external instrumentation with built-in ports.
Readouts - MEA: Yes, for cardiomyocytes or neurons in certain chambers. ALine can embed electrode arrays or align them to a base MEA circuit.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: A major offering: O2, pH, metabolite sensors in each organ chamber. Real-time data used for feedback control across multiple organs.
Dead Volume: Minimized, but multi-organ circuits can have more tubing. ALine’s engineering approach keeps volumes as low as feasible, using microvalves and short channels.
Perfused: Yes, advanced multi-loop or single-loop perfusion. Pulsatile or cyclical flows are possible. Automated medium switching for each organ if needed.
Gas Mix Controlled: Can design partial gas-permeable compartments or sealed plastic for specialized O2 conditions. Typically external environment or media-based O2. They can incorporate individual organ environment controls if required.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Highly programmable. Valves can isolate compartments or unify them, dynamic flow changes, periodic drug dosing, mechanical stretch in certain compartments, etc.
model_availability: Fully custom engineering from ALine. They build multi-organ platforms to user specs. Used in NASA projects, multi-organ disease modeling, etc.
